summary: members of the Parvoviridae family are small non-lipid enveloped viruses with a diameter of 18–26 nm, icosahedral symmetry (T = 1). the subfamily of densovirinae contains four genera: Densovirus, Iteravirus, Brevidensovirus and Pefudensovirus. the bocavirus genus was recently assigned to parvovirus genomes containing a third ORF (labeled HBoV3 was first reported in the stool of australian children with non-polio acute flaccid paralysis [10], then in australian children and Chinese children with diarrhea [9], [25]. HBoV4 was reported in the stool of children with AFP from Nigeria and Tunisia [5], and then in untreated sewage water from throughout the US [26]. a novel bocavirus was identified in the feces of captive gorillas with diarrhea [6] and from wild go porcine bocavirus 1 (PBoV1-H18) and porcine bocavirus 2 (PBoV 2-A6) were also screened for in 340 stool samples of asymptomatic swine from five provinces of china. the nearly complete genomes of both viruses were described here. samples were suspended in PBS (0.01 M phosphate, pH7.2–7.4, 0.15NaCl), vortexed, centrifuged at 15000 g, and filtered through a 0.22-m filter to remove eukaryotic- and bacterial-cell-sized particles. the samples were then treated with benzonase, DNase and RNase to digest non-particle-protected nucleic acid. rose gel and were gel purified (Axygen, CA, USA) then subcloned into pMD-18T plasmid vector (TaKaRa, Japan) for sequencing. sequences were then screened for sequence similarities using tBLASTx and BLASTn against the nr database in GenBank. primers PBoV1-L1 (5′-CTGTGGCACTTCAGATTTAC-3′) and PBoV1-R sequence and phylogenetic analysis Sequences of each PCR product were assembled using seqMan II program (DNASTAR, Inc) the identification of open reading frames (ORFs) was performed by a translated BLAST search (BLASTx at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/blast/Blast.cgi) 340 porcine stool samples from different aged swine were collected from 17 middle or large-scale porcine farms in five provinces of china from April 2008 to October 2009. 80 were collected from four farms located in Shanghai, 60 from three farms located in Jiangsu province, 120 from six farms located in Anhui province, 20 from a farm located in Shandong province and 60 from three farms located in Guizhou province. anhui 6 PBo-likeV (FJ872544), PBoV1 and PBoV2 (HM053693 and HM053694), and 6V and 7V (HM053672 and HM053673). protein amino acid distances were calculated using the neighbor joining (NJ) method with bootstrap of 1,000 replicates with MEGA 4.1. the 24 sequences from porcine sample A6 were assembled to form a continuous sequence of approximately 2700 nucleotides. PCR primers based on the available H18 sequences and regions highly conserved between HBoV2 and canine bocavirus were used to amplify the nearly complete bocavirus genome we provisionally called PBoV1-H18 (5267 nt) the black boxes represent the known spliced exon of NS1 transcripts. prevalence of PBoV1 and PBoV2 Nucleic acids were extracted from 340 porcine stool samples. a group (except for the V6/V7 variants with only NP1 sequences available) were most closely related to the canine bocavirus CnMV. PBoV2-A6 was closely related in NP1 to the first reported partial porcine bocavirus sequence PBo-likeV from Sweden. PBoV1 PBoV2 6V 7V HBoV1 HBoV2 HBoV3 HBoV4 GBoV1 CnMV BPV1 PBoV1-H18 NS1 - 51.8 - 52.9 51.7 - 59.6 58.6 59.4 59.2 59.7 55.8 65.8 NP1 - 62.3 0 64.2 62.2 - - nine samples (totaling 82 subclones) showed the presence of fragments whose virtual translation products were related to canine and human bocaviruses using BLASTx. clones from pig sample H18 and 26 clones from pig sample A6 showed significant similarity with bocaviruses. the ORFs of PBoV1-H18 were 636 aa for NS1, 219 aa for NP1 and 621 aa for VP1/VP2. the black boxes represent the known spliced exon of NS1 transcripts. the prevalence of PBoV1-H18 related viruses was high in china. 133 out of 340 (39.1%) samples were co-infected with both PBoV1-H18 and PBoV2-A6 related viruses. phylogenetic analysis of the nearly full-length genomes of PBoV1-H18 and PBoV2 were performed. oV1 and PBoV2 and 33 representative bocavirus species/strains (A) Phylogenetic analysis of nucleic acid and amino acid of NS1 (B and E), NP1 (C and F) and VP1 (D and G) ORFs of PBoV1-H18 and PBoV2-A6 and representative bocavirus species/strains. a sequence of PBoV2-A6 related variants from different farms was also phylogentically analyzed and fell into two major clades we named PBoV2 genotype 1 and 2 (PBoV2-G1 and PBoV2-G2) the two previously described Chinese PBoV1 and PBoV2 “species” grouped within these two genotypes. the PBoV2 clade belongs to the still partially characterized bocavirus clade. the partial NP1 and VP1 genes of PBoV1-H18 related viruses were more highly conserved (99–100% identity) PPV4 clustered phylogenetically with the bocaviruses but instead clustered with members of the parvovirus genus [59] PPV4 is therefore unrelated to the bocaviruses reported here. HBoV1 has been associated with respiratory symptoms while other HBoV may be associated with diarrhea and acute flaccid paralysis.
